column2: This is an official title when you are referring directly to the actual programme, so is in upper case; if not, then use lower case.
Use title case when referring to the business area covered by Money Laundering Regulations. Don't use the acronym.

Title case. 'Activation PIN' has been changed to 'Activation Code' on outgoing correspondence from the Government Gateway. Until all hard coded instances of Activation PIN have been removed from the Online Services pages, use:
'Activation Code (also known as Activation PIN)'.
Lower case. Only cap up when using the full title, eg Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.
Acronym should come first as it's more widely known than the full name. Please note that the acronym has changed to 'Bacs'.
Cap up if it's a specific named team. Always lower case for 'team' and generic names like research team, youth offending team.
Always lower case unless it's part of a proper title, eg 'The DFT's management board', 'the Judicial Executive Board'.
Lower case even in a name, eg Northampton borough council.
Not even in the title of the business plan (publication title).
Lower case in text. Cap up in titles, eg Spencer Tracy, Chairman, GDS.
The acronym should come first as it's more widely known than the full name.

column1: chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear (CBRN) materials.
column2: Lower case but use caps for the acronym.
Lower case except where it's a title with the holder's name, like Chief Constable Andrew Trotter.
Named benefit, but generic references to tax credits are lower case.
Upper case because it's the name of an organisation.
Lower case in all instances, including 'the coalition'.
Not 'third party software' or '3rd party software'.
Only cap up if used as the full title: the National Assembly for Wales (Legislative Competence) (Social Welfare) Order 2008.
Use upper case when referring to the actual Construction Industry Scheme, (CIS', not 'the CIS').

column1: Corporation Tax for Agents online service

column2: Use uppercase if referring to the actual service, not if you are describing using the service.
Lower case even in a name, eg Wandsworth council.
Lower case even when referring to the defence team at the MOD.
Lower case except when in the title, eg the Department of Health.
Lower case in text. Cap up in titles, eg Spencer Tracy, Director, GDS.
Lower case even in a name like Warwick district council.
Leave unabbreviated to distinguish from the European Community. Write out in full at first mention, then call it 'the Commission'.
Use EU when you mean EU member states, eg EU countries, EU businesses, EU consumers, goods exported from the EU, EU VAT numbers, etc. EC should be used when it's EC directives, EC Sales List, etc.
Upper case because it's a brand name.
Lower case in text. Cap up in titles, eg Spencer Tracy, Executive Director, GDS.
Lower case even when referring to 'the fire and rescue service'.
Lower case even when specific, eg Afghanistan government, UK government.
Upper case because it's the name of a programme, but note that it's Green Deal programme, Green Deal team, Green Deal assessment etc.
Not a title, just a descriptor: don't cap up any named guidance eg national recovery guidance.
Lower case unless part of a proper noun, eg Cardiff Harbour Authority
Not a title, therefore lower case.
Lower case unless it's the title of an organisation, eg North East and Central London Health Protection Unit.
Lower case h in hurricane and upper case K for Katrina because it's a name.
Names of benefits take initial caps.
All names of taxes take initial caps.
Lower case even when it's 'the law'.

Lower case, eg the legislative competence orders (LCOs) are approved, rejected or withdrawn. Only cap up if used as the full title: the National Assembly for Wales (Legislative Competence) (Social Welfare) Order 2008.
Upper case as long as it's a specific named organisation, not trading standards services in general.
Always use the National Lottery if that is what you mean.

column1: Machine Games Duty for Agents online service

column2: The member states are descriptive; it's not a title.

column1: minister - health minister, climate change minister, communities minister, foreign office minister etc
column2: Use upper case for the full title, eg Minister for Overseas Development, or when used with a name, as a title, such as Health Minister Norman Lamb. Note that when used without the name, shortened titles are lower case, as in 'The health minister welcomed the research team'.
Don't use Member of Parliament, just MP.
Lower case when referring to the activity not the regulation.
Lower case. Don't cap up any named strategy, eg national health and welfare strategy.
Subsequent references would be 'the assembly'. Lower case is also used for the second assembly, the third assembly.
Lower case in text. Cap up in titles, eg Spencer Tracy, Non-executive Director, GDS.
Not a specific region of the UK.
Upper case because it's the name of an organisation.
This term covers both company and public sector pension schemes. Only use this term if explaining tax rules that apply specifically to occupational pension schemes.
If used adjectivally, hyphenate and use 'one' rather than '1'.

Lower case unless part of a proper noun. HMRC Online Services should be in title case when referred to in full. Equally if you want to refer to a named service, it should be in title case, eg 'Submit your company tax return using Corporation Tax Online.'
Lower case even for 'the opposition'. Also for opposition leader Ed Miliband.
Only cap up if used as the full title, eg Standing Order 22.
Lower case even when naming a specific council.
Parliamentary takes an intial capital and committees is in lower case.

When referring to the product/relief/regime, then say 'the Patent Box'.

Occasionally the definite article will be dropped. Examples of this are:

in calculations - where we use 'Patent Box deduction'
when using phrases such as 'Answers to your Patent Box questions' etc
This can be abbreviated to 'PAYE Online' within the 'PAYE Online for employers' area of the website.
Lower case, even when referring to 'the police'.
Lower case. Note that 'police force' is usually avoided.
Upper case because it's a brand name.
Upper case because it's the name of an organisation.
Use 'Prime Minister David Cameron' and 'the Prime Minister'.
Lower case, eg Troubled Families programme, Sure Start programme.

This is an HMRC programme and should only appear either with initial capitals or as an acronym when referring to the programme itself. When describing customer processes, use common language phrases like 'send your payroll information to HMRC' or 'operate your payroll in real time', but don't say 'send your payroll under RTI', or use the acronym like 'in RTI' or  'under RTI'.

Cap up 'Regulations' in the full title, eg Licensing of Animal Dealers (Young Cats and Young Dogs) (Scotland) Regulations 2009 or  the Fruit Juice and Fruit Nectars (England) Regulations 2003, but usually 'the licensing of animal dealers regulations'. No comma before the date.
When a group that has a very generic title (eg working group, research team) it should be lower case. Note that 'team' is lower case, eg youth offending team, Behavioural Insights team.
When a group that has a very generic title (eg X working group, Y research team) it should be lower case.

The Secretary of State for XXX is capped up whether or not it's used with the holder's name because there is only one. Use common sense to cap up shortened versions of the SoS titles such as Health Secretary. The rule for ministers is different because there is more than one.
As in part of an act or a strategy.
This compound noun should be hyphenated, unless it's an HMRC title.

column1: Self Assessment for Agents online service

column2: Use 'Self Assessment tax return' the first time it's mentioned on a page. After that use 'tax return'.
Lower case, even when referring to the armed forces services or the services.

The Shadow Secretary of State for XXX is capped up whether or not it's used with the holder's name because there is only one. Use common sense to cap up shortened versions of the Secretary of State titles, eg the Shadow Health Secretary.
This acronym means small and medium enterprises. Use SME for the singular.
The Spending Review is a thing. But where it's not the thing, we are conducting a spending review.

column1: Stamp Taxes for Agents online service

column2: Only cap up if used as the full title, eg Standing Order 22.
Because it's the name of a programme. Note that programme is lower case.
Not a title, but Working Tax Credit and Child Tax Credits are specific benefits, so take caps.

Title case the first time they are mentioned, (for example: 'Company Tax Return', 'Partnership Tax Return', 'Employer Annual Return'). After that refer to them in full, or if it's clear what you're referring to, simply as a 'return'. General references to tax return are always in lower case.

When referring to the legal requirement we use 'deliver' or 'file' the return. Online, we say 'submit' the return.

For Self Assessment (paper or online) use 'send' or 'file' the return. 'Send' is better.
Lower case, eg youth offending team.
Even for a name, eg Swanage town council.
When used to refer to the business area covered by Money Laundering Regulations.
Upper case because Twitter is a trademarked name.

column1: VAT EU Refunds for Agents online service

column2: Used when referring to all the online services for VAT.
Hyphenated when used as a compound adjective.
Lower case, except when it refers to a field within a form.
Use 'VAT Return' the first time it's mentioned on a page. After that use 'the return'.
Subsequent references would be 'the assembly'. Lower case is also used for the second assembly, the third assembly.

column1: Welsh exotic animal disease contingency plan

column2: Named benefit, but generic references to tax credits are lower case.
